After I read this book, I wish the conflicts Brian had faced will not happen to me too.  I wish this not because 13 year old Brian's parents have divorced and he now has to fly over from his mother’s house, to his father’s house in the north by himself.  His plane crashes onto an unfamiliar forest and he needs to learn to survive on his own.
I sometimes like to be by myself, like when I want to read, watch YouTube, or get some rest.  But I wouldn’t want to be isolated.
When he crashed, he had to overcome mental and physical conflicts.  He needed to recover from his crash landing, the feeling of being isolated, and accepting that he was unattainable from help.  However, he remained positive.  One by one, he came up with solutions to each of his problems.  He figured out where to find fresh water, edible foods, and how to protect himself from bugs and animals.  Throughout his incident, his hatchet that was a given to him from his mother still remains.  He uses the hatchet to build the key to his survival.  He creates fire, collects wood, and offers a protection to the outside predators.  The hatchet remains with him to the end even when he swam into the huge lake to retrieve the survival kit.
Brian was adapting to his environment when a tornado led Brian to be discouraged.  It destroyed his shelter and all his efforts.  But the tornado also brought Brian a chance.  The plane that had sunk to the bottom of the lake, had been brought up. Brian was given two risky choices.  He either stay safe in his shelter or risk his life to swim and retrieve the survival pack.  He decided to stay positive and choose to swim to the plane and get the pack.  When he got the pack, he activated an emergency transmitter that contacted a nearby pilot and was rescued.
Lastly, the reason why Hatchet made such an impact on me was because of how the story presents, even though unfortunate events could come your way, you will get stronger because of the hard trials and hardships.  Throughout the book, Brian grows to achieve more and more advanced challenges and later successes in overcoming all of his hardships.

The community Jonas lives in, people can not feel emotions, see color, or have the ability to choose for themselves.  Jonas begins to realize how wrong this was when he started to train to become the next Receiver of Memory.  The Receiver of Memory’ s job, is to receive memories of the past.  He receives good and bad memories from a wise man who tells Jonas to call him the Giver.  While everybody else in the community is clueless about the past and even what is current, Jonas needs to take full responsibility of bearing the weight of all the memories.
During his training, he asks the Giver to tell him about the Receiver of Memory who failed to bear with the depression and pain of the memories.  The Giver tells Jonas the whole truthful story and Jonas realizes what would happen if he failed like the last Receiver of Memory, Rosemary had.  If he failed, all the memories he received would spread to the rest of the people in the clueless community and put them in chaos.
Jonas then asks what happens to people that are released. With horror, he understands that they without any say, get killed with a shot that gets injected into their bodies.
Jonas realizes this isn’t right and that people should be able to feel, do, see, and have the choice in what they do with their lives.  He then hatches a plan with the Giver for him to escape the community.  When I read this, I was very confused why they decided to so this.  Then I realized that if his plan did succeed, the community would get all the memories he had, making them be comprehensive of how the world used to be like and how it is now.
The plot of the Giver was great.  However, the ending of the book was very disappointing.  The author finished the book without an ending therefore making readers guess what happened next.  I think the purpose of that was so that readers would use their own imagination to finish the book.  I wish there would have been and happier ending for Jonas.  He sacrificed so much, leaving his family, friends, comfort and his security in the community.  I think he should have deserved a better ending. So for my conclusion of the book, he finds another community, is accepted and lives a long happy life.

My favorite scene in Maze Runner was when, Chuck, a teenager younger than Thomas, sacrifices himself from the flying knife meant to kill Thomas.  Chuck had been the one that immediately started comforting Thomas and encouraged him to be resilient when he arrived in the terrifying and unknown community.
Thomas, a teenager arrives in a glade from an elevator in the center of a great maze. Like the other dozens of male teenagers who arrived there before him, Thomas has no memories except his own name. He desperately tries to find, what is going on, but the other teenagers, had no avail.  However, the Gladers did tell him about the hideous and violent creatures that come out in the maze during the night called Grivers. Toward the end of his first day, he asks his only friend Chuck, about the Gladers whom he just watched run from the maze into the safety of the walls protecting the Glade from the maze and Grivers.  Chuck answers telling him those were Runners who run into the maze everyday to try to find  way out of the Glade.
Immediately, Thomas wants to become a Runner despite that you could die.  When I read Thomas wanted to become a Runner, I thought he was going insane.  If I were him I would be crying my eyes out for the parents I don't remember!  The very next day, the elevator provides another newcomer despite that the elevator comes only once a month.  If that wasn’t crazy enough, was that the teenager that was sent up was a girl rather than a boy.
Teresa, the girl, tells Thomas important information, the maze is a code.  The walls don’t close for the night, exposing Gladers to the Grivers. Everynight Grievers take one Glader one by one and kill them.  Thomas, not being able to wait for there cessation by the Grievers, he studies the maps, runners have kept track of for the past two years stays and resilient.  He soon figures out the code, and escapes the maze, only to find the maze was a test, and they only passed phase one, and phase two was coming.
I think the moral of Maze Runner, is resiliency.  The reason why I think this because throughout the whole story, readers see how when a conflict is thrown at him, he remains calm and finds a solution to the conflict.

Warcross is a novel about a world, where the game Warcross and Neuro Technology has changed the way people live. Warcross is more than a game but a lifestyle, to everyone everywhere, including Emika Chen and tennagers worldwide. Emika is a teen bounty hunter and hacker struggling to stabilize her life when she hacks into the opening ceremony of the Warcross Championships. When she tries to make a bit of cash by stealing a rare powerup from the ceremony, she unintentionally reveals her hacking live to the world. This accident  scores her a job at Henka Games, the Neuro Tech company. Hideo Henka the rich, famous and young C.E.O himself whisks her off to Tokyo, Japan. This job offers all she wants with enough money to pay her rent and live a comfortable life, but this glorious job is not all what it seems.The initially incredible opportunity tangles Emika into the dark world of crime, family secrets, mystery and even murder. This suspenseful, science fiction book, offers exciting, fascinating themes. The captivating personalities of the characters creates a plot engaging from the first page. I highly recommend this book because of its gripping description and twisting plot.

This book is not your stereotypical love story. It's like Star wars and Stranger Things but with more fantasy, magic, and mythical creatures. Young Sophie Foster is quite the protagonist and very different from others like Luke Skywalker and Harry Potter. Sophie is an extraordinary character because she has many magnificent abilities such as Telepathy. She's been on many adventures with hers friends, Dex, Keefe, Fitz, Biana and only a few with Linh and Tam. She's brave and will do anything to protect the people she loves.  This book is good to help kids expand their imagination and think outside of the box. In this book Sophie and her friends help the Alicorn population grow, prove that Fitz's brother is not innocent because he was part of the Neverseen, and at the end of the book Sophie Foster will go to get matched only to face a shocking surprise. This story also includes a lot of romantic stuff, it's about  trust and who you should trust.  The characters are quite unique and they all have amazing personalities. The plot is so interesting that's it's hard to put the book down! So then, I would definitely recommend this book to most kids, they should definitely read this series.

column6: Jennifer L. Holm and Matthew Holm
column12: Sunny side up is a sad, but heartfelt story. It's about a girl named Sunny who goes to Florida for an unknown reason for most of the book, but as we get closer to the end we start to find out why. While she's there she lives with her Grandfather. While her grandfather is out to get something she meets a boy named Buzz while getting soda. Buzz is a boy about Sunny's age and likes comics. He introduces Sunny to comics and they get along great. They get golf balls and then trade them for money to get comics. Sunny starts getting flashbacks to why she's actually here in Florida. Sunny's brother Dale has an alcohol addiction.  Though she is a bit sad, she didn't let her stop it from making memories. At the end of Summer Vacation, Sunny goes to the airport  to fly back to her family. Even though she feels sad she had to leave she's happy because she made a lot of great memories while she was there. This book is good because it enlightens kids about alcohol abuse and that it's a bad thing. A lot of kids who's family members have an alcohol problem can relate to this story and hopefully speak up about this problem. The characters were quite optimistic and that helped Sunny become optimistic too. The images did a good job of portraying the story. So overall this is a good book and would definitely recommend this to maybe 6th grade to any ages.

column4: The Wright Brothers How They Invented the Airplane
column12: THE WRIGHT BROTHERS How They Invented the Airplane is about the Wright Brothers when they were young and how they grew to inventing the airplane. The two brothers Wilbur and Orville Wright grew fixing their toys when they broke them. They grew up to work in their father’s bike repair shop. They eventually had an interest in aviation and started engineering planes. Out of the two brothers I like Wilbur. Wilbur is the oldest out of the two brothers and I think it would mean he has more responsibility than Orville. Wilbur was also the first out of the two brothers to test fly their airplanes. The writing style of the book is very simple. There aren’t really any hard words in the book which makes it easier to read. As a non-fiction book I think  the information was very accurate. It really explained everything in detail which is good. This book includes  pictures, which is making the book easier to read and provides the reader with these images to help the story move forward. I think the pictures did help the story move on, providing pictures of the models of their airplanes and the history of the two. Pictures make books more aesthetically appealing which is what happened here along with much more. I would recommend this book for middle school students. This book is inspiring which is good for young readers.

The Voyages of Doctor Dolittle is a book about a boy who has a care for animals and finds one hurt in the wild. The boy brings the animal, a squirrel back to his home. He  is unable to help the squirrel and seeks for someone’s help. He meets this guy  named Doctor Dolittle and that is where their adventures begin. They go on voyages leading them to the mysterious Spidermonkey Island. Who knows what mysteries lurk on the island and the things they will do? I really like Tommy Stubbins and Doctor Dolittle. They are the main characters in the book but also the smartest ones. The writing style is very easy to read,  but there are some words that might be a little hard for some readers. There are pictures in the book which really give readers an image of what is going on in the story. Overall I really enjoyed reading the book and would recommend to 1st-6th graders. Even though that is my recommendation age it can still be enjoyed by middle school students and even adults. It’s award-winning and a great fictional and adventurous novel. The ending is a really good feature about this book. It ends with a statement that makes you want to read more. The author also illustrated the book making it more interesting.

The Hate U Give is a story about discrimination. It starts when the protagonist, Starr, goes to a party with her friend Kenya. Kenya ditched her though, so Starr walked around trying to find someone else to talk to. She soon found her childhood friend Khalil and they started catching up. They then heard gun shots a few minutes later, so they ran to Khalil's car and drove away. They were really happy that they could finally catch up. The happiness didn't last though, for they were soon pulled over and Khalil was shot for suspicion of having a weapon. Starr was angry and heartbroken. People rioted about this discrimination. Starr organized a lawsuit and was afraid of the police ever since. They still didn't get the justice they deserved, so Starr joined another riot and spoke the truth about why Khalil died. Starr spoke out at least 3 times after Khalil's death because she felt the need to tell people that discrimination is a serious thing and that you should never be judged because of your skin color. I recommend this book to people because discrimination is big problem and we need to enlighten people about it. The age group I would recommend this to is 6th-12th graders. The characters all had different personalities which made them unique. The story has good detail and the tension increases as the plot thickens so the book is quite hard to put down!

column4: Google The Company And Its Founders
column12: GOOGLE THE COMPANY AND ITS FOUNDERS is a book about Google and how it all started. The internet has a problem, people can’t find what they are looking for on the web. The two people Sergey Brin and Larry Page have an idea. This is where Google came into mind. The decided to make a browser that would make finding things on the web more efficient. This was the start of a new time that would change the way the internet works. Out of the two, I don’t think there is a favorite. Their company was a partnership which means they both started it, owned it, and worked together on it. They are equal. The writing in this book is fairly simple and there aren’t really and hard words. This book is non-fiction, and I think the information is very accurate. This book also has pictures which I do think moves the story on. The pictures also really show what the words are describing in the book. I  would recommend this book to 4-8 graders. Even though it’s my recommendation I still think others can enjoy it. It’s very informative and you can learn a lot about the search engine millions of people use.

The Mark of The Dragonfly has no clear lesson, but the book is quite interesting. The book is about a girl named Piper. Piper lives in a town full of hoarders or in other words, a scrap town. Piper herself is hoarder, but one day during a meteor shower everyone was waiting inside for it to be over and collect all the good scraps. Though Piper couldn't wait and went out while the storm was still going so she could get  better scraps. Piper's friend was worried about Piper so he ran after her. Though he soon got hit by a meteor. Piper took him somewhere to heal and she continued looking for scraps until she came upon a cart which people from the Merrow Kingdom used to get to the Scrap Town. Inside the cart was a girl who had the mark of the dragonfly. Piper taught the how to do regular human things and they went to the Merrow Kingdom to return her to her home. Though, Piper soon found out that Anna was no normal human being and was actually a robot! Anna went to go find the person who made her and he tried to kill her and Piper in the process. Anna and Piper finally found their way to the Merrow Kingdom's King and Anna didn't want to stay there. Anna wanted to stay with Piper. So they stayed together on a train with Piper's boyfriend, Anna, and the train crew. This book was quite interesting and I recommend it to 6th-12th graders. This book helps kids expand their imagination and be more brave. The characters are all different and each have a different aspect that makes them special. The story line was amazing, so it's hard to put the book down!

ELECTRIC DREAMS is about a group of high school students who are building a car. The car though isn’t just any normal car, it’s a race car! This group is trying to engineer a race car for a race at Richmond International Raceway. They have little time to pull off a life changing experience. The group goes to the race and competes for the win. It’s a test, a test to see what women can do, and a test to prove women can also do things men can do. I can’t really decide if there is a favorite or superior character in this book. The women all work in a group to engineer a car to race and win. They are a group and work together which is something you can’t take away from them. The writing in this book was fairly simple although there are definitely some tricky words. This is a non-fiction book and the info that was given seemed correct and believable. I think I would recommend this book to middle school  students, high school students, and adults. The reason I chose middle school  students as my recommendation group is because there are some tricky words in this book which would make it hard for young readers.

column4: Almost Astronauts 13 Women Who Dared To Dream
column12:
Almost Astronauts 13 WOMEN WHO DARED TO DREAM is about a group of women who are unfairly treated for their gender. Men discriminate them and say they can’t become astronauts. These women go through tests to try to become astronauts and prove they can do what men can do. They prove they can become astronauts. After lots of time taken away by training and being put through tests, the group of women become astronauts. Who knows what they will do next? Out of the thirteen of them I think Jerrie Cobb is the best one. She was the best one in the group and definitely  the more prominent out of the thirteen. She worked hard and was put through lots of trouble. Though this all happened, she proved herself worthy and earned what she had worked for. This book’s writing is pretty easy. It’s simple, easy to understand,
and there aren’t really any hard words. This book was non-fiction. I think the information is believable and it’s a true story. The book contains images which definitely help the story move on. The pictures show what is going on and what the words are talking about. I would definitely recommend this book to 4-8 graders, specifically girls. There is a reason for this. This book is about women and talks about discrimination towards women and gender equality. Although this is about women and should probably be read by girls it an amazingly inspirational story and can be enjoyed by anyone.

Rocket Boys is about a group of boys who live in a small town called Coalwood. The four are limited to knowledge and information about what is going on outside of Coalwood. One of the boys named Homer Hickam learns about a satellite flying above Coalwood and gets an interest for rocketry. They try building rockets themselves. They end up going to a science fair and winning. Homer’s dreams come true and Coalwood is proud of Homer. Who knows what Homer will do in the future? There are four boys in the group. Out of the four I definitely think Homer is the best. He’s smart, he’s dedicated, and most definitely the leader of the group. The writing in this book if fairly simple  although there are a few words that may be tricky for younger readers. This book is non-fiction. The information that was given and the story all seem true. This book does contain images but only a few of them. These images do in fact help the story. The pictures give a visual concept of what the words are talking about and what is going on. I would recommend this book to 5-8 graders. This is because there are a few words that might make this book tricky to read for some younger readers. This book is also very inspiring and informative which is good at a young age. Even though this is my recommendation, high school students and adults can enjoy this book as well.

column4: The Hive Queen: Wings of Fire book 12
column12: Wings of Fire: The Hive Queen is a book about Cricket and  her friends. They embark on a quest to get the book of clearsight and tell the truth about Queen Wasp to the Hivewings. Cricket is hiding in a cave from Queen Wasp and waiting for her friend Blue to hatch from is cocoon. Though when he does eventually hatch, he's not ordinary Silkwing. He's a rare FlameSilk. This means he makes a special kind of silk. She needs to tell all the citizens that Queen Wasp has been lying to them before it's too late. Her parents also seem to hate her, but they aren't her parents. Her so called sister "Katydid" is actually her mother. She's also immune to Queen Wasp's mind control powers because she was born without Queen Wasp knowing. Can she be  able to stop a war? The characters are great, they have a lot of personality and they are all types of dragons! The writing style was great, the plot was really good and the tension increases as the story continues. The age group I would definitely recommend the book because then kids can get a sense of creativity and imagination by the fact there's dragons in this book. I would recommend this to is 6th to 12th.

The book Stargirl is about a girl named Stargirl. She is new at school and is quite   odd. She is far from your average popular girl. She easily steals Leo's heart. She is popular for a while, but it doesn't last. Since a girl named Hillary is really popular she made everyone hate Stargirl. Though, not everyone turned against her. She still had   a small group of friends and Leo. Leo was dating Stargirl in secret so no one knew, until Stargirl told everyone. Leo and Stargirl became quite unpopular and everyone stopped talking to them. Stargirl won a contest and no one cared and she was still unpopular. Leo didn't like all the negative attention so he made Stargirl the only thing she wasn't. Stargirl was soon a normal girl that looked like every other girl at that school. The only thing was she was still unpopular, Leo and Stargirl spent a lot of   time together and soon Stargirl was back to being her normal self. Though, soon she disappeared without any reason. The characters were your pretty typical high school people, but the story line was great nevertheless which makes the writing style really good. This story is really relatable to high school life and I think something from this story that you can learn is that no matter if people don't like yo or not there will always be people who will. I will definitely recommend this book to people from 6th-12th grade.

The Story of DOCTOR DOLITTLE is about a man named Doctor Dolittle. He loves animals and has the ability to speak to them. One day a surprising call comes from Africa with a problem. The doctor travels there to help the problem. Monkeys in Africa are dying of a terrible epidemic!  Who knows what else he will do there and what problems he might face? This was the beginning of new adventures, and new experiences. Doctor Dolittle is definitely the best character in the story. As the main character he goes through a lot and is experiencing everything going on in the story. The writing style in this book is very simple. There aren’t any hard words which make the book enjoyable and easy to read. This book contains images. These images are really helpful to the story. They give a very nice visual aspect of what is going on in  the book. I would recommend this book for 4-7 graders. Even though this is my recommendation it doesn’t necessarily only have to be read by this age group. It is an amazing fictional story that can spark imagination. It can also be enjoyed by high-school students, college students, and even adults!

Amulet: The Stonekeeper is the first book of the Amulet series. This book is about a girl named Emily. It starts out as her, her brother Navin, and their mom move into  their great grandfather's house. They start to clean the house and everything is fine  at first. Though, they notice the house seems really odd. While cleaning, Emily and her little brother Navin go to a room upstairs. There Emily finds an amulet. She puts it on and goes back downstairs with Navin because their mom is calling them. Their mom hears a strange noise coming from the basement. She brings a flashlight with her and goes to see what's wrong she looks around though when she looks behind her, to her horror she screams. Emily and Navin hear this mom's scream and go to see what happened. They get there to only see her flashlight. They see a path  leading outside. They follow the path and start running to find her. The amulet starts glowing and it tells Emily to go to a certain place. They go there and they start going on the hunt for Emily and Navin's mom. The characters are pretty typical, though I  like the fact the book gives a lot of insight of the character and the characters get good development. The plot was really good, before it was really calm then the tension increased because their mom was kidnapped. The images did a great job of explaining the plot. You could see everything happening. I would recommend the book because it's quite thrilling and it's quite inspiring too. The grade levels I would recommend this to is 7th-12th.

In the book Posted, there is a group of four friends who go to the same school. They all met each other on a field trip. They're been together ever since. At their school a  lot of kids use their phones in class or anywhere. They all have been through times together and they all have different personalities. Though,  one day during math class a girl named Ruby was on her phone and her teacher caught her sending a horrible message about a teacher. This caused the school to ban phones the next day to prevent any events like this from happening in the near future. The phones were to  be left at home or dropped off at the office and to be picked up after school. Most students thought this was preposterous. Though soon, the four boys found a way to communicate by posting post-it notes on each others lockers. Soon a lot of kids started doing this. At first the notes were friendly and nice and soon they had insults. Posted is a book about friendship and hardships. The characters have strong personalities that make them stand out from other characters. The story was really confusing at first but as it progressed it started to become good and I could understand it better. I would recommend it to 6th-12th graders because they can learn how words affect people.

Doctor Dolittle’s Circus is about Doctor Dolittle and his experience with a circus. The doctor needs money for a voyage to Africa so he decides to join the circus. The doctor loves animals and has the ability to speak to them. During his time at the circus he helps many animals that weren’t under good care and gets into a problem there that has to do with fox hunting. Who knows what else he might do there?

The BattleMage is book about a boy named Fletcher. Fletcher is a blacksmith's apprentice in a small town. One day a soldier comes to his town with objects from the battle field and he gives Fletcher a special book. That's when Fletcher discovers he has the rare ability to summon demons. When people Fletcher blame Fletcher for a crime he is forced to run away. He travels a long distance far away from his past village and finally finds a school for this special ability he has. He meets many friends there and also some people who think they are better than everyone else. He learns that his demon is actually quite rare and he also learns how to cast different spells  like a shield spell. With rivals and friends Fletcher has the fate of the world in his hands. Can he win a war or not? The characters in this book were unique, some of them had interesting aspects about them, while some were only a bit unique. The plot was really good, and the book was hard to stop reading. I would recommend this book to 6th-12th graders because the book is encouraging and it helps kids develop creativity and imagination.

Doctor Dolittle in the Moon is a book about Doctor Dolittle and his trip to the moon.  He meets someone on the moon along with moon animals and plants! The doctor like he does to his other animals, learns to speak to them! There is a problem though. Will they ever let Doctor Dolittle leave? Who knows what might happen to him on the moon?! The best characters in this book are the main ones. Doctor Dolittle and Polynesia are those characters. Out of the two I think Doctor Dolittle would be the best character. The writing style of this book is a little hard. There are some words that might make the book hard to understand. This book includes images which really help the progression of the story. It keeps things moving forward by giving a visual of what is going on during the progression of the story. I enjoyed reading this book and would recommend this book to 5-8 graders. There are some words that are specifically for the level of 5-8 graders. I recommend 5-8 graders to read this book because they would be able to understand this book well compared to younger readers. Even though this is my recommendation this book could be read by anyone willing to do so.

column4: Keeper of the lost cities: Exile
column12: Exile is a book part of the Keeper of the lost cities series. In Exile Sophie Foster finds herself being a very powerful telepath. She is sent on a mission to Exile, a place for unstable creatures. She is sent there to find the personal who made the special person she is right now, she wanted to know why the Black Swan was sending her notes. Though before this, Sophie and her friends were out in the forest looking for something. Sophie spotted something so she ran after it. Once it finally stopped she'd realized she had found an alicorn. Though when Sophie finally found the leader of  the Black Swan he seemed odd and when Sophie read his mind it was blank. Alden felt guilty for this and fainted so Sophie took him back to Everglen. He was in a coma, but soon Sophie figured out how to heal him and he was all better. Can she heal a broken mind though? The characters in this book are all different in unique ways. The plot always focuses on one main point and when we are so close to finding an answer to a main question in the book it ends on a cliff hanger. This makes the book worth reading and hard to put down. I would definitely recommend the book to anyone who likes fantasy or anyone who has a struggle with fitting in because they can relate to the protagonist Sophie Foster. The grade level I would recommend this to is 6th-12th.

column4: Keeper of the lost cities: Everblaze
column12: Everblaze is a book part of the Keeper of the lost cities series. In Everblaze Sophie, Keefe, and Fitz face new Villains, the Neverseen. In the last book Sophie was kidnapped and she's determined to find out who kidnapped her. Sophie finds herself face to face with her kidnapper, a pyrokinetic. All her allies were with the building with her as they interrogated Sophie's kidnapper. Though Sophie was caught off guard when the pyrokinetic suddenly formed a ring of fire around them. Everyone got out safe except Councillor Kenric. Kenric was the only councillor that always supported Sophie. Sophie was sad that he died. She used this sadness to prevent any more of the people she loved from getting hurt. Later she finds out the Black Swan was using her and her friends to draw out the Neverseen. She demands a meeting with them, but when she gets there she sees someone who she didn't expect to see. Overall, Everblaze is a bit of a sad book. The plot was quite calm, but then the tension started increasing and the plot twist happened. The characters are quite unique, because they all have different personalities. I would recommend this book to 6th-12th graders or anyone who has lost any loved one from a casualty because it helps people move on and it also helps enlighten kids about casualties.o has lost any loved one from a casualty because it helps people move on and it also helps enlighten kids about casualties.

Doctor Dolittle’s Return is the continuation of the book Doctor Dolittle in the Moon. It is about the return of the doctor from the moon. The doctor has returned from the moon and is eager to write a book about all of his experiences. But there is a  problem. The sadness of his experiences on the moon are being compared with his funny experiences of trying to be put in jail so he could write his book. The main characters in this book would be Doctor Dolittle and his assistant Tommy Stubbins. Out of the two I think Doctor Dolittle would be the best. He’s been going through so much on the moon while Tommy was waiting for him. The writing style in this book is pretty easy. Even though this may be true, there are still just a few tricky words in this book. Otherwise, it’s easy to read and understand. This book has images that really help the progression of the story. They show what is going on in the story. I really like this book and would recommend it to 5-8 graders. This because there are some words that may be a little hard to understand for younger readers.

DOCTOR DOLITTLE’S ZOO is the story of Doctor Dolittle and what he did after returning from his previous voyages. Now that he has returned, he plans to set his house in order and expand his zoo to benefit some of the animals he has there. The doctor can talk to animals. This helped him help them. The main characters in this story are Doctor Dolittle, Polynesia, Matthew Mugg and the group of rodents. The doctor loves his animals. That is why he is trying to help him. The rodents are mentioned in the book a lot and are found in the majority of the pictures in this book. They are very important characters in this book. The writing in this book is very easy. There aren’t any hard words in this book which makes it easy to read and understand. This book contains pictures which show what is going on in the book. It really helps having pictures in this book to make it easier to understand. I really liked reading this book and would recommend it to 1-5 graders and older. This book’s writing is easy, making it easy to understand. This is why the recommendation age is so low. It can be enjoyed by anyone!

column4: Doctor Dolittle and the Green Canary
column12: Doctor Dolittle and the Green Canary is a story relating to the story of Doctor Dolittle’ s Circus. It’s about the green canary and her adventures. The doctor can speak to  her and thus listens to her stories. She tells the doctor and the other animals about the story of her master and interested by the story, are determined to find him. Who knows if they will find him? The main characters in this book are Doctor Dolittle, Pippinella, and Dab- Dab. Out of the three Pippinella seems to be the most important character in the book. She is the Green Canary. The story is about her and revolves around her. She is very important to this story. The writing style in this book can be a little tricky. There are only a few words that could be confusing and make the book hard to understand. This book to me was okay, and I would recommend it to 6-8 graders. This book isn’t really meant for younger graders to read and it also might be harder to understand because there aren’t any pictures in the book. It is still a great book and can be enjoyed by middle school students and high school students.

DOCTOR DOLITTLE’S POST OFFICE is the story about Doctor Dolittle and his love for animals. In the story the doctor helps capturing a slave trader’s ship and he organizes a postal service. King Koko begs him to take charge of the post office to try to get it back into shape. Later in the book he discovers an island populated with a ton of prehistoric creatures! Doctor Dolittle also gets thrown in another jail. Who knows what else will happen in this story? The writing style in this book isn’t that  hard. There are only a few words that may be hard to understand. This book contains images. These images are very helpful to the progression of the story. They show what the story is talking about and what is going. I thoroughly enjoyed reading this book and all the other Doctor Dolittle books in the series. I would recommend this book to 6-8 graders. The hard words in this book made me bring the grade recommendation higher. The story starts with a slave ship which is something younger readers won’t understand which is why the age recommendation starts at 6th grade. But the lowest is 6th grade because this book is fiction. Fictional books spark imagination which makes them great to read.

“Why Forgive” is a book about people and the sad things they encountered. It’s about people doing things to them that didn’t seem okay. In this book you will read about  the tragedies that 7 people have faced or committed. It’s about the sad things people do. There characters in this story are Hashim who got shot and was paralyzed for the rest of his life, Carol’s husband who committed adultery, Delf who backed a pick-up truck over his son, Josef who escaped the Holocaust, Kate who was abused by her alcoholic mother, Bill’s son who was killed by a drunk driver, and finally Marietta’s daughter who was kidnapped and murdered. They all faced and had done terrible things. They are all main characters in this story. The writing style of this book is fairly simple for older readers. Some of the words in this book are a bit hard, making the book harder to read and understand for younger readers. This book is nonfiction and the info seems correct and true. This book contains images which make the book easier to understand. They help cover up the hard words and give a visual of what is going on in the book. I really like this book and would recommend it for 7-12 graders, that includes 7-8 graders and high school students. This book’s story is a little bit inappropriate for younger readers and they can’t really understand what is going on in the book. Even though this may be true, it is still a great book and its’ story can be enjoyed by many people.

column4: Nightfall: Keeper of The Lost cities
column12: Nightfall is a book part of the Keeper of The lost Cities series. In Nightfall, Sophie and her friends go to Nightfall to find her human family. With her sister save from the Neverseen, Sophie needs to act fast. She struggles to find her human parents with the little clues she’s given. Though, the Neverseen kidnapped her human family, they didn’t find her little sister. Sophie, worried for her little sister that she might be taken too, takes her to the city of elves. She is awestruck because of how different Sophie’s world is from the human world. She explores elven culture, while Keefe and Sophie are trying to figure out where the Neverseen are. Keefe was a fake member of the Neverseen and gathered information for Sophie and her friends. His mother was a member of the Neverseen. Though, Keefe was the only one in his family to now know until now. Keefe’s father knew, but Keefe didn’t. Though, Keefe is able to give Sophie information about the Neverseen and Sophie eventually finds her human parents. The characters are really unique and they all have different personalities. The plot is really good and the tension increases a lot at one point. I would recommend this book to 6th-12th graders because it helps their imagination grow and it also helps them understand how you family is so important.

THE HIGHEST TIDE is the story of 13-year old Miles O’Malley who goes exploring  on the tidal flats. There he discovers of a giant squid and instantly becomes famous. All the people then wonder whether the boy is observant or a prophet. Discovering this squid was the start of his story. Who knows what will happen next? With Miles O’ Malley as the main character he is definitely the best character in the book. This story is about him and him adventures. This is about what he experiences. This is why he   is the best and most important character. The writing style in this book kind of hard in this book. There are some words that make the book hard to understand. This can make the book challenging for younger readers. I really liked the book and would recommend it to 6-8 graders. As a fictional book it isn’t really meant for older readers to read this book. The book supports imagination which is great for young readers! Still the recommendation group is a little high due to the hard words in the book. Even though this is true, it is still a great book and can be enjoyed by many people!

column4: STAR WARS Guardians of the Whills
column12: STAR WARS GUARDIANS OF THE WHILLS is the story of two guardians named Chirrut and Baze. The two were guardians of the Whill. They looked after the Kyber Temple on Jehda and everybody who worshipped there. One day the Empire came and took over Jehda. They sealed the temple and everybody scattered. Now, after resisting the Empire, Baze and Chirrut do all they can to deny the Empire and strike back for the people of Jehda. But are their efforts worth the cost? Baze and Chirrut are the main characters in the book. Being the main characters give them an important role. Out of the two I think Chirrut is my favorite. He is brave and wise. What more do you need? For a fiction book the writing style in it is a little hard. They are quite a few words that may make the book hard to read and understand. This book does contain images which really help make the book less confusing with the hard words in it. I really enjoyed reading this book and would recommend it to 5-8 graders. Being a fiction book it’s good for young readers. The hard words in the book though made me bring up the age level. Even though this may be true this fiction book based on the movie Rogue One: A Star Wars Story is a great book that can be enjoyed by anyone.

THE GIVER is the story of a boy named Jonas. Where he lives, the rules are strict. People can’t choose their family, their job, and no one asks questions. Everybody obeys the rules. In his community there is no conflict, inequality, divorce or choice. There aren’t really any problems in his community, but there are problems of choice. In this community everybody is the same and follows the same rules. Except for Jonas. There is a ceremony in this community. The ceremony in which children receive their predetermined life choices. Ones they did not choose. The main character in this story is Jonas. As the main character Jonas is put in a very  important position. The writing style of this book is quite hard. The are some words in this book that can make it hard to read and understand or  young readers. Overall, it’ s a great book and I really liked reading it. I would recommend it to 7-8 graders. The book contains words that might make the book hard to read for younger readers. The topic of the book and just is book in general is meant  for middle school kids rather that younger readers like elementary school kids. It is still a great book and can be enjoyed by many.

Invisible man is the story of a nameless young black man who journeys from the Deep South when black men like him are killed by fighting animals. He leave the south for New York City and yet his encounters still disgust him. He has though met people who have changed his perspective on being a black person in a white country especially since he never really knew himself in the first place. Eventually he has had enough and goes to find a hole in the ground where he then furnishes it and tries to find his true identity. The main character in this book is a nameless young black man. Being the main character of the story revolves around him. It’s about him. The writing style in this book is a little hard. There are some words in this book that can make it hard to read and understand for young readers. I really enjoyed reading this book and would recommend it to 7-8 graders. This is because of: the hard words in the book and what the book is about. I think the book would normally be for older readers, but it is still a great fictional story that can be enjoyed by many people.

FINDING ORION is the story about a boy named Rion and his weird family. His older sister Cass, wearing purple lipstick and hum-rapping songs from Hamilton. His younger sister Lyra, pigtailed and reading a pocket dictionary discovering new words to show off with. His mom and dad sitting shoulder to shoulder as if it was required by law to be sitting within kissing distance. Then Rion himself with elbows on the table and hands pressing his cheeks staring at the little piece of candy on his plate thinking that he was definitely adopted. During Christmas Papa Kwirk pays them a visit and  he brings the most unusual gifts. From, all the all events happening in the book like chicken flavored jelly beans, a wacky funneral, and a crazy scavenger hunt. There isn’t anything you can’t get out of this book. There is so much going on in the book! Who knows what else happens?! Out of all the characters in this book, I think the most important is Rion. He is the main character in the story. Everything is about him and his family. Mainly him. The writing style of this book isn’t hard at all. There aren’t any hard words in this book which make it easy to read and enjoyable. I really liked reading this book and I would recommend it to 3-8 graders. The lack of hard words in this book make it easy to read for young readers. Also the fact that it’s fiction means that it’s perfect for young kids!

I funny is a very funny and deep book.The protagonist is in a wheelchair and is an orphan a clice thing, I know but a very common one.He lives with the bully and a very sad family, living with a bully does not help their mood a lot.His uncle who owns a popular diner in the seaside town.Our protagonist Jamie Grimm Has a grim story  both parents dead and sister dead to as a cherry on top.He has to compete in this comedy contest so he can be named long islands funniest kid comic.He has to get through some challenges he has detention and he has to deal with bullying, girls and so much more.When the big day comes he wins and all is well.This story is very good while some parts are boring and forgettable the finale is UN forgettable the build up he might lose but he wins we see him change friends girls pressure from school and home it is all and all a great story.

Over the summer, Katie Brown didn't spend a single second worrying about middle school. But when the first day of middle school comes, Katie is taken by surprise when her best friend Callie would rather hang out with a bunch of mean girls then with Katie, leaving her friendless. Katie quickly starts to panic, wondering what would happen to their friendship. Luckily, Mia, Alexis, and Emma sit with Katie, and Katie doesn’t feel so lonely after that. Throughout the book, Katie, Mia, Alexis, and Emma become best friends, and form a Cupcake Club. When their school announces that they are having a fund-raiser, they decide to sell cupcakes.
Katie Brown is very energetic, bold, and doesn’t really like change. She is an only child, and is very close with her mom. She loves baking cupcakes and hanging out with her friends. Mia is from Manhattan and is very fashionable, chill, she stands up for her friends, and doesn't make a big deal of of anything. Mia has one older stepbrother, her parents are divorced but she sees her dad every other weekend.
She also is very close to her stepdad, Eddie.  Alexis is very business-like and professional. She has an older sister that she goes to for advice. She doesn't like to get dirty, and she is very organized. Emma is shy and has two older brothers and one younger brother and she can not stand them. Emma is a model and also works as a dog walker. Callie was Katie’s best friend but would rather hang out with the new friends she made from camp. Callie is still nice, nicer then her friends, and buys a cupcake from Katie at the fund-raiser.
The writing style of this book is realistic fiction, and it uses a first person point of view. I would totally recommend this book, it is great for grades 4-8. You can really bond with the main character (Katie) and you can read the other books in the series told by Katie’s friends Alexis, Emma, and Mia.

It is Word War II, and two best friends are forced to crash land in Nazi-occupied France. They are separated in enemy territory, and one is captured by the Gestapo right away. The first part of the story is about Queenie, her code name being Verity, which means truth. She must decide whether to face torture or cooperate with her captors. She chooses the latter but reveals her knowledge through a story of her friendship with Maddie, who is believed to be dead. The second part of the story is of Maddie. She tries to figure out a way to save her friend with the French resistance, and return back to Great Britain.
The book is historical fiction, and it reveals many facts and difficulties from the time period. For instance, there were very few female pilots. Also, the first part of the book is a confession and is very similar to a narrative. The second part is written in a pilot’s log by Maddie. Both describe the struggles and events going on through their writing. In the writing, stories of their life, friendship, family, fears, and many other ideas show up and enrich the story along with occasionally adding humor.
The book allows the reader to see two perspectives on the situation and hides many clues that would be hard to find reading it the first time. The book has a major plot twist at the end which reveals the result of the entire mission.
I would recommend this book, especially to readers who enjoy historical fiction. I enjoyed it because the plot had me hooked, and I wanted to know what would happen next. The details gave me a good understanding, and the characters were very well developed. The book reveals the struggles of war and allows readers to understand the hardships of the two characters. The story will make you wonder if you would be able to do the same actions and question how strong your own friendships are.

"When given the choice between being right and being kind, choose kind." This is a quote from the award-winning book, “Wonder” by R. J. Palacio. Wonder is a book about a boy named August (but most people call him Auggie) who starts middle school. Auggie has never been to a real school before, because of a rare disease called Treacher Collins. Auggie is nervous, and he gets bullied. But Auggie, later on, finds a new friend. Jack Will. At first, Jack only hangs out with Auggie because he feels bad, but later on, finds out how cool Auggie can be, and they become best friends. Jack talks bad about Auggie behind his back, so Auggie hangs out with a girl named Summer. In the end, Auggie and Jack become best friends again.
The characters in this book are Auggie, Summer, Via, Jack Will, Auggie’s parents, Julian, and much more. Auggie is the main character in this book and his best friends are Jack Will and Summer. Jack Will is Auggie’s friend from the beginning but later talks bad about Auggie. They eventually make up and Auggie forgives him. Summer is optimistic, kind, and outgoing. She does not only hang out with Auggie because the principal told her to. She did it because she wanted to show kindness. Summer is always by Auggie’s side and always stands up for him. Via, or Violet, is Auggie’s big sister. She is caring, kind, and great at acting. Sometimes she  is jealous of the attention that Auggie’s parents give him, but at other times, she can be an understanding sister. Auggie’s parents are very protective of Auggie. They are very understanding of Auggie’s problems, and always make time for him. Jullian is obnoxious, insecure, and a bully. He makes fun of Auggie just because of his face.  He is quick to judge and does not care about other people’s feelings.
The book “Wonder” changed the world. It opened people’s eyes to how someone would feel having a facial deformity. It also taught people that you should never judge a book by its cover, and always be kind. It shows how cruel the world can be and how you should always stick together with the people you care about. “Wonder” is a great read for families, and I think everyone should read it.

Everything that Emelina Flores has ever loved has been taken from her. Her home was destroyed by war, her parents were killed, and her sister was kidnapped. But  now it is time for her revenge. Even without the powers of her fellow Ruined, Emelina will prove she can still do plenty of damage. Emelina plans to get revenge on the royal family of Lera since they are responsible for Emelina’s suffering. She plans to pretend to be the betrothed of the crowned prince, Prince Casimir, as a way to infiltrate the castle. She will lead an ambush on the castle, and kill the king, along  with everyone he loves. But how will her plans change when she falls in love with the prince? The complexity of the characters and the character growth they experience throughout the story, make them seem like real people. The relationships between the characters are very believable as they express hate, love, and trust towards one another. In addition to this, the characters reflect on their past decisions with emotions such as regret and sadness that show very well in the writing of the book. Because of how close to human these characters are, it is easy to care about them as they are forced to make hard decisions that will change their lives. I would recommend this book because it is beautifully written, with many twists and turns, and the story’s fast-pace ensures you will never be bored. The book is filled with action that keeps you on your toes in anticipation as you wait for something big to happen.

After The Seven Stages of War, the Earth became barely habitable. As a result, the next generation’s leaders must be chosen very carefully. Candidates to be a leader are chosen to take part in The Testing, only if they pass can they go to University. Cia Vale is one of these candidates, which makes her very proud. But the night before leaving for The Testing, her dad, former Testing candidate and a University graduate, tells Cia the traumatizing effect The Testing had on him and warns Cia not to trust anyone. The Testing is filled with hard tests, causing many injuries, including death. In addition to this, the other Testing Candidates are determined to get into University, including sabotaging the other candidates. Cia must make smart decisions if she is to make it through The Testing and get into University. The characters seemed very realistic and their emotions were beautifully displayed in the book. The story was very realistic, which helped me visualize the setting and the things the characters were experiencing. However, the book started off slowly,  making it hard to get into. The story is action-filled and makes you think as you experience the adventure with them. I would recommend this book because it was so hard to put down after I started reading it. There are many plot twists that keep the book interesting and keeps you on your toes.

Jennifer E. Smith’s romantic novel, Field Notes on Love, is the story of two  soon-to-be college students. One of them is afraid of love while the other has been left with a broken heart and an extra train ticket to travel across America. They both come from two different worlds, but the strangers soon find they have more in common than they realize. As they grow closer so does the time for them to say goodbye, but how can love survive the distance of an entire ocean?
The second I picked this book up I became entranced by how smoothly it is written. Every word and phrase felt significant, yet I never felt overwhelmed by all the descriptions and details.
The way the author switches perspectives between the two protagonists each chapter allows the reader to better understand the characters. While I was reading this book, I felt almost as if I were there watching each scene. The imagery truly paints a beautiful picture.
Overall, I would recommend this book to anyone who enjoys a novel filled with romance and adventure. It kept me on the edge of my seat until the very end, and is one of the most wonderful books I have ever read.

Percy Jackson, the demigod son of Poseidon, takes you into the world of Greek gods and heroes as you learn about each of the twelve Olympians and a few extra gods. He takes you way back to the time before humans, all the way back to before the earth. He tells you the many things from the big things, like how the Earth was created, to the small things, such as how the flute was created. Percy Jackson teaches you about each god’s past, linking one story to the next, each god to each other. He shows you each of the gods’ powers, faults, and many funny stories about them.
Percy teaches you the basics of Greek mythology in a fun and engaging way. Percy’s humor and jokes make the book easy to read and laugh at. The pictures made it easy to visualize the Olympians’ power and just how frightening they were to the people from the past. The writing beautifully weaved in Percy’s personality to the classic Greek stories.
I would recommend this book because it is a fun way to learn Greek mythology. This book is also the kind of book that you could read over and over again. Every single time I reread it I could not put the book down.

“I thought about Steven and the Old Man and Izzy and I put my hand on my chest because there was such an ache inside.” Hollis Woods is abandoned as a baby and spends her life living in various foster homes. She tells what happens between the time she spends with Josie Cahill and the summer she spent with the Regan family, who wanted to adopt her. “Pictures of Hollis Woods” is a novel by Patricia Reilly Giff, and it is a great read for all. The main characters of the book are Hollis, Steven, Josie, Old Man, and Izzy. Izzy, Old Man, and Steven are part of the Regan family.
They love Hollis and adopt her. Josie is the foster parent that is fostering Hollis and has a very special connection. Even after Hollis runs away, she still hears Steven’s voice in her head, and can’t stop thinking about the Regan family, and how they were the only people in her life so far that truly cares about her. In the end, she realizes how much she misses the Regan family and finds out that she belongs with the Regans. This is a great book about a girl who searches for her forever family, there are flashbacks, fast forwards, and everything in between.

column4: To All the Boys I've Loved Before
column12:
Are you looking for a book about the terrifying journey of falling in love? Then Jenny Han’s novel, To All the Boys I’ve Loved Before, is the book for you.
Lara Jean is a hopeless romantic. She loves to read about it, but romance is a scary thing for a junior in high school. That is why Lara Jean keeps her crushes sealed up in five love letters that are hidden from the rest of the world. One day, everything changes. The letters Lara Jean wrote aren’t so secret anymore, someone sent them out. She attempts to keep her older sister’s ex-boyfriend from finding out she is in love with him. However, Lara Jean ends up starting a fake relationship with another one of the recipients of her love letters. As Lara Jean tries to bring her life back to normal, she realizes that she may be falling in love all over again.
Throughout this book, the reader can truly connect with the protagonist. The author does an amazing job of describing the thoughts and emotions of Lara Jean. It is as if you are looking at the story through Lara Jean’s eyes because you see the good, bad, and the in-between moments.
All in all, I would recommend this book to anyone who enjoys a modern-day love story. This novel sucked me in right at the beginning, with its original yet relatable plot. After all, being in a relationship, real or fake, is challenging.

Percy Jackson, the demigod son of Poseidon, introduces you to Greek’s mightiest heroes. With the classic Greek heroes: Perseus, Psyche, Phaethon, Otrera,   Daedalus, Theseus, Atalanta, Bellerophon, Cyrene, Orpheus, Hercules, and Jason, Percy Jackson teaches you the basics of each hero showing you each hero’s best moments as well as their most embarrassing stories. Percy teaches you how the Olympian gods influenced each hero’s lives in a good or bad way. With stories such as how Theseus slew the Minotaur and how the Amazons started, the book is packed with information and humor.
Percy Jackson once again gets us laughing with his humor and funny jokes, even when the stories are serious. The many pictures ensure you understand the dangerous situations each hero had to overcome. The book is beautifully written thanks to Rick Riordan’s ability to weave one’s personality into a classic story.
I would recommend this book since it is an easy and fun way to learn about classic Greek heroes. The book is easy to reread and get more information out of it each time you read it. This is a good book for those who know a lot about Greek Mythology and for those who don’t since you could always learn something new from this book. The book is almost impossible to put down once you start reading it and will keep you laughing at all the hilarious jokes.

Obsessed, by Allison Britz, is an astonishing memoir in which the reader is immersed in the author’s battle with OCD.
Allison is a pretty normal teenager. She has a best friend, a crush, and can’t stop thinking about the prom. Then one morning her whole life suddenly gets turned inside out. A terrifying nightmare about getting brain cancer begins to haunt Allison, and she finds the only way to calm her anxiety is to listen to the unfamiliar angry voice inside her head. While endeavoring to stop her dream from becoming a reality, Allison begins to shut everyone and everything out.
The author does an amazing job of conveying the hardships and challenges that come with obsessive-compulsive disorder. Through this book, the reader can become more educated about OCD through a real-life story.
In every chapter of this memoir, there is an ongoing fight between the protagonist and herself. Every emotion the author describes is powerful. As I was reading this, I felt like I could truly understand the main character.
Through sharing her story the author has created a beautifully written book. Overall, I would definitely recommend this memoir to anyone looking for a book about the internal battle life can be.

When Friendship Followed Me Home is an emotional rollercoaster for young adult fiction readers. An adopted, lonely boy named Ben meets a stray dog (Flip) who becomes Ben’s best friend and a much-needed confidence boost. Together, they bump into The Rainbow Girl, Halley, daughter of the librarian and Ben’s first true friend. The problem? Halley has cancer. Determined to write 111 books in her lifetime, Halley and Ben become very close and Begin writing together. When a sudden loss shakes Ben and forces him into a new home, he and Halley must learn to overcome life’s unfortunate endings and consequences. Paul Griffin illustrates a wonderful, shining story with love, loss, and laughs.

After rescuing her sister Olivia, Em returns to Ruina where she and Olivia work together to restore their former kingdom. Olivia proposes a diarchy so that she and Em may rule Ruina together. However, as they start to work together, their wants and views of the future clash. Olivia wants to punish those who opposed the Ruined, but Em wants peace. Em believes that with Cas on the Leran throne, peace is within reach, but Olivia worries that Em’s feelings for Cas may be clouding her judgment.
Em now faces must make the difficult choice of either betraying her only family to bring peace or allow a war to save her family from falling apart once again.
The writing of the book is beautiful as the emotions and thoughts of each character is displayed. The characters are, once again, very human-like in their complexity, and Em’s feelings towards Olivia and Cas makes you understand her struggle in choosing between the two of them.
I would recommend this book because of how beautifully written it is and how relatable the characters are. The book makes you never want to put the book down again with action that ensures there is never a boring chapter.

All Em wanted for the people of Ruina was peace but as Olivia’s intentions of  revenge against those that wronged the Ruined became clear, Em can only hope that she could change Olivia’s mind. However, Em is not the only one who disapproves of Olivia’s violent ways, many other Ruined also feel the same way and join Em in trying to stop Olivia from causing more destruction. As Olivia realizes that Em had betrayed her, their distrust towards one another becomes clear and both know that a war between their own race might be in their near future, but only will be victorious.
The characters were very realistic and as you get to know them more, you start to care about them. The feelings you develop for the characters make you feel bad for them and sometimes, scared for their lives. The dialogue was beautifully written like the characters were real people talking, and as the characters created new bonds with each other, it displayed beautifully within the writing of the book.
I would recommend this book because the writing is beautiful, and the characters are complex and human-like. However, the book was slower than the previous two, the book still keeps you at the edge of your seat as you worry about each character’s life.

Stephenie Meyer’s New Moon continues the Twilight Saga, showing once again the power of love.
Bella Swan thinks she has seen it all. Last school year, she fell in love with a vampire named Edward Cullen, met his family of vampires, and then got attacked by other vampires. Finally, everything seems to be back to as normal as it can be, so can’t  true love just be left alone once it is found? Apparently not. Suddenly, the Cullen family disappears without a trace, and Bella’s whole life seems pointless without Edward by her side. While Bella attempts to cover up her unbearable wound, she gains a best friend: Jacob Black. Then one day, Jacob joins a mysterious cult and disappears from Bella’s life. With two of the most important people in her life gone, how will Bella survive?
Through the author’s sequel the reader gets to know the protagonist even more and the depth of her emotions. Meyer paints a vivid picture of the anguish that Bella feels. As you get closer to the end of this novel, you will also get closer to understanding Bella Swan’s heart.
All in all, I would recommend this novel to anyone who fell in love with Twilight and was on the edge of their seat waiting for more.

column4: To All The Boys I've Loved Before
column12:
Lara Jean wrote letters to all her crushes but ever wanted them to be sent. She wrote one to five boys, including her first kiss and her sister’s ex-boyfriend, Josh. However, when she finds that all of her letters have been sent out, she does everything she can to make sure Josh thinks she no longer has feelings for him by telling him she is dating Peter, another recipient of a letter. Peter, who wants to make his ex-girlfriend jealous, decides to go along with the lie. But can a fake relationship inspire real love?
The writing of this book is very descriptive, and the characters are very relatable and act like normal teenagers. The personalities of the characters are interesting and lovable with faults that make them seem like real people. The relationship between the three sisters is so funny and sweet because of how close they are. They are like every sibling relationship since they love and hate each other but still help each other out.
I would recommend this book because of how interesting the story is and how lovable and sweet the characters are. Once you start reading it, you will not be able to put it down.

After fighting with Peter at the Christmas Party, Lara Jean makes up with Peter. However, a video from the Ski Trip of Lara and Peter making out in the hot tub leaks all over the internet causing rumors to spread. Peter defends Lara and tells the  poster of the video to not mess with Lara Jean. John Ambrose McClaren, a recipient  of a letter who had moved away, contacted Lara Jean, and the two became pen pals. Lara Jean holds a 7th grade reunion and invites everyone including John. Peter invites his ex-girlfriend causing Lara Jean to be jealous while Peter is jealous of John. Could Jealousy tear the two apart?
Jenny Han captures teens perfectly in the way they act and think. Lara Jean’s emotions show strongly in the writing of the book and makes you feel them along with her. With the addition of John Ambrose McClaren, the story gets even more exciting and interesting. As you get to know the characters better the more you love and hate them.
I would recommend this book because it is a beautiful story, and the characters are so lovable and believable that you could just get absorbed in the story. You will not want to put it down once you start it.

Lara Jean is the happiest she has ever been with a trip to New York, prom, Beach week, and her dad’s getting to Ms.Rothschild, and she is going to the University of Virginia with her boyfriend, who got a sports scholarship for lacrosse. However, when she gets some unexpected news that she has been rejected from the University of Virginia, her whole plan seems to fall apart. Will their relationship last the obstacles life will bring?
The writing is, once again, beautiful and nicely brings the trilogy to a close. The characters and their relationships are lovable it is sad that this is the final book. The relationships are very realistic as the couple fight and make up. Ms.Rothschild instantly becomes a mother figure to Lara and makes you love her instantly. While reading this book, it is easy to get absorbed into the story. The family relationships are so realistic as they get mad at each other or support each other throughout the book.
I would recommend this book because the story is so exciting and beautiful that you could just fall in love with it. The book is so interesting that you cannot put it down.

Tell me three things is a young adult novel written by Julie Buxbaum. It is a mystery/romance genre centered around the life of a teenager named Jessie, still getting over the death of her mother who died from cancer. Her father eloped with a rich actress and they moved to a small wealthy town. As Jessie tries to fit in with the rich kids at her private school, and deal with bullies and boys, she also tries to piece together who is sending her text messages and emails about her new environment.
It is clear Buxbaum is trying to portray Jessie as a bullied girl who's dead mom is taking a toll on her social life, but Jessie is a very unlikeable character. She is very aggressive at parts of the book, such as saying she thinks of beating her father until he bleeds and begs for forgiveness, and thinking she wished her father died instead of her mother. Buxbaum tries to get the reader to feel sorry for her by including tough situations, but Jessie outdoes that by being aggressive and annoying.
The ending is both predictable and surprising, because you thought the person who wrote Jessie all those messages would be someone you never expected, perhaps the girl who was bullying her, or someone who was hiding from the shadows, but it is the person that was so obvious all along and provided no surprise or excitement at the end. The very ending, the person who was sending her all those messages, it was the reason people keep reading. But the person who you have been waiting throughout the entire book to find out is the bland obvious guy. The 'surprising ending' was just a deflated helium balloon slowly exhaling air. Nothing to look at but it's at least something.
This book is not a good read. Very predictable, no exciting moments, doesn't leave you thinking. Simply bland, boring, and cliche. Do not recommend reading, waste of time and waste of money. This book is a 1 out of 5 stars.

Sadie is a young adult mystery novel written by Courtney Summers. Sadie Hunter is  a girl that went missing from her small town Cold Creek. When popular radio personality West McCray gets a call from an anonymous person begging to help find Sadie, he decides to start a radio series dedicated to finding Sadie. Sadie fled her town after her younger sister Mattie was found dead, burned in a fire. She is intent on finding Keith, the man who dated her mother and left, believing that he murdered her sister. Switching POV's back and forth between the radio series transcripts and Sadie, it is a wonderful mystery.
The switching POV's is one of the best parts of the story. You put the pieces together throughout the story, finding out clues that the characters don't realize. Hearing both sides makes you really feel like you are in the story, helping McCray find Sadie.
Summers is a very talented author who uses descriptive words and good angles to help the reader see the story from all sides and really immerses them in it.
Sadie is a very relatable character who you can understand. The book brings in things that everyday teens relate to, involving parent fights, and angsty moments.
Sadie's pain, shock, anger, and happiness really sticks to the reader, and you feel for her, every single moment. The suspense and shock and thriller really gets to you.
You can't stop reading, always wanting to see what comes next. And it is always  worth it. The twists and turns in this book are amazing. Summers could make watching paint dry an interesting read. There is never a dull moment in the characters and the plot.
The ending is surprising and shocking. At the very ripe moment when you finally figure out what is going to happen to Sadie - will she come back? Will she die? Will she be gone for good? What happens to Sadie? The best part of reading is using your imagination to think up what happens next. No spoilers should come up, but the ending is something seat gripping and sweat dripping, and will leave you satisfied for long after you finished reading.
Sadie is an amazing read that leaves you on the edge of your seat. Summers is a creative talented author that will make you feel so much. Definitely read this book.

column4: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban
column12:
Harry gets fed up with the Dursleys while staying with them in the summer, and accidently blows up his aunt. Harry isn't punished for this and soon finds out why: turns out, a dangerous prisoner, Sirius Black, has escaped from Azkaban and is hunting down Harry. When Harry returns to school, everyone is preoccupied with fear of Sirius Black. Soon Snape shows up and we learn the shocking truth, Sirius Black is innocent and Scabbers the rat is really Peter Pettigrew, in Animagus form, which gives him the ability to turn into an animal at will. Voldemort's servant and the real criminal. Meaning, Sirius was framed. it turns out Sirius Black is a good guy and Harry's godfather. But Pettigrew escapes and Sirius is captured by the Dementors.
Harry and Hermione use a device to turn back time, and they manage to help Sirius escape.
The main character of this book is Harry Potter. He is brave, loyal, and selfless. His best friends are Ron and Hermione, and they are always by his side. He recently discovered his godfather is Sirius Black and they form a very close relationship.
I think this is a wonderful read and Harry Potter is a great role model for kids. However, younger grades might not understand some parts of the story, as some of it is confusing. This story is a wonderful example of loyalty and forgiveness.

Seattle has been experiencing many mysterious murders, which Edward suspects are a bunch of bloodthirsty newborn vampires who are craving human blood. When Bella goes to visit Jacob, Jacob confesses his love for Bella. Alice soon has a vision that the vampire Victoria has come to kill Bella in revenge for Edward killing her mate, James. Bella has once again found herself in the middle of conflict and now faces a new decision between Edward and Jacob, knowing that choosing either one can make the old conflict between vampires and werewolves much worse.
The story is very interesting and fun to read. The dialogue makes the characters seem real and it is fun to see them interact. The relationships between people are very realistic. Each character is very well developed. Also, the emotions Bella experiences are displayed very well in the writing. The story is very original and the world Meyer has created expands with every book. As Bella faces tough decisions it feels like we are there with her, struggling to make a choice.
I would recommend this book because it is a good continuation of the Twilight series. The book is very engaging and the story is easy to get absorbed into that you will never want to put the book down again.

Cia Vale is ready to begin her university education at the Commonwealth’s University with her boyfriend Tomas. Her memories of her Testing wiped from her memory, Cia must decide if she should believe the voice on her Transit Communicator that tells her what happened during the Testing or continue her studies with the rest of the University. But as memories of her past come back in her nightmares, Cia must  figure out who she can really trust. However, the more digging she does, the more dangerous her path becomes. Cia must decide whether to continue on this new path or stay put to keep her friends and family safe.
The characters are very realistic, with the exception of Cia, who is unusually perfect. The characters are different from one another with different skill sets that make each of them dangerous. The writing is marvelous, and the story keeps you thinking as Cia solves each problem that is thrown her way.
I would recommend this book because of how action-packed it is. Even though the storyline is very similar to most dystopian series, the book is still beautiful. As soon as you pick it up, you won’t be able to put it down.

Cia Vale might be the only one who can end the testing and stop a civil war that can kill many innocent lives. Cia must decide who to trust and who might sabotage her efforts. However, she must decide whether she can risk the lives of those she loves. Cia is determined to do whatever it takes to end the testing that killed many bright minds and her friends, even if it means having to kill the people she once admired.
The story is very interesting and keeps you thinking as Cia tries to solve the problems that are thrown at her.
